awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Novel Synthetic Applications of Poly(cationic) lambda-3 Iodanes
awd_abstract_narration:
With this CAREER award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports the research of Professor Sarah Wengryniuk in the Department of Chemistry at Temple University. Professor Wengryniuk and her students develop innovative approaches for the synthesis of medium-sized (7-10 atoms) oxygen-containing ring compounds. These challenging molecular scaffolds often have unique biological activities. The Wengryniuk lab develops novel methodology based on a new class of environmentally friendly, low toxicity nitrogen ligands.  The first goal of this award is to develop new cyclization modes to access 5-8 membered rings. The second aim applies new methodology developed in the Wengryniuk lab to the synthesis of the Heliannuols, enabling the development of these medium-ring natural products as novel environmentally-benign herbicides. This funding also supports the establishment of an all-female mentorship team the Temple "OWLS" (Outstanding Women Leaders in Science) which will participate in K-8 outreach, science fair mentorship, and summer research internships for high school students.  The team also sponsors an annual Women In Science symposium to help young women to prepare to pursue advanced degrees and leadership roles in science and engineering fields. 

Hypervalent iodine reagents (HVIs) are powerful tools in organic synthesis due to their diverse reactivity, low toxicity, and low cost. Professor Wengryniuk recently reported the first synthetic applications of (poly)cationic lambda3-iodanes (N-HVIs), an underutilized class of hypervalent iodine reagents which display unique and divergent reactivity from traditional hypervalent iodine reagents. This research leverages unique expertise and ongoing efforts in the development of these powerful reagents as new methods for total synthesis and umpolung approaches to carbon-hydrogen functionalization. Specifically, this research develops novel approaches to the synthesis of diverse oxygen heterocycles through umpolung activation of alcohol functionalities. This team further leverages a novel ring-expansion methodology discovered by Professor Wengryniuk for the synthesis of medium-ring benzoxepane and benzoxecane natural products.  Heliannuols are a new class of environmentally benign herbicides. This funding also supports the establishment of an all-female mentorship team the Temple "OWLS" (Outstanding Women Leaders in Science) which participates in activities designed to help young women prepare for advanced degrees and leadership roles in chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
To meet the pressing needs of today’s society, chemists continue to seek out more efficient, affordable, and environmentally sustainable methods to access molecules of importance to the agrichemical, pharmaceutical, and materials industries. With the support of this CAREER award, our laboratory sought to contribute to this cause through the development of sustainable strategies to access important carbon-oxygen and carbon-nitrogen bonds, which make-up the backbones of small molecule drugs, herbicides, and synthetic materials that support our daily lives.

To this end, we developed new ways to form valuable carbon-oxygen bonds that do not rely on the use of expensive or toxic metal catalysts, but rather earth-abundant iodine. These reactions were designed via reversed-polarity or “umpolung” bond forming processes, wherein we disconnect molecules in the opposite ways of traditional chemistry, opening up new opportunities. We developed a metal-free approach to synthesize aryl ethers, valuable motifs in the pharmaceutical and other commodity chemicals, through the activation common benzylic alcohols. This strategy allowed the synthesis and biological investigation of multiple members of the heliannuol family of natural products, molecules which are produced by the sunflower, and represent potential environmentally-benign, next-generation herbicides and pesticides. We also developed new approaches to access pyridinium salts, valuable scaffolds present in pesticides, antibacterials, and even human cells. Our research allowed their synthesis from simple, ubiqitous hydrocarbon-based feedstock compounds and we used simple iodine-based compounds, or even just electricity, to activate the desired sites for carbon-nitrogen bond formation. We were then able to show that from a single pyridinium salt product, one could do further reactions to access small libraries of diverse piperidine molecules, one of the most common scaffolds in FDA-approved drugs.

The pursuit of these research objectives provided a diverse team of graduate and undergraduate researchers with invaluable opportunities for scientific training and professional development. Students who participated in this work have gone on to top graduate programs in STEM fields or to prestigious positions within the pharmaceutical industry, including over a dozen students from under-represented groups. The outreach intiatives supported by this award provided science fair mentorship to underprivledged communities in North Philadelphia, and established the Temple O.W.L.S. (Outstanding Women Leaders in Science), a multifaceted program aimed at providing mentorship, sponsorship, empowerment, and professional development to women in STEM at Temple University and the broader community. 

 


Last Modified: 05/26/2023
Modified by: Sarah Wengryniuk
